items.title: 2013 Chevrolet Cruze Uses New Air Bag Technology
items.author: By Cheryl Jensen
items.abstract: General Motors says the new technology deploys the air bag more efficiently, while providing crash protection that is equivalent to, or better than, more expensive and complex dual-stage air bags, depending upon the type of crash.

items.title: Obama’s Chance for a Fresh Start on a Climate-Smart Energy Quest
items.author: By Andrew C. Revkin
items.abstract: President Obama’s inaugural address stresses the need to press on energy frontiers and cut climate risks.

items.title: Apps and Other Digital Tools Lend a Hand to New Mothers
items.author: By Claire Cain Miller
items.abstract: Digital tools offer new mothers help with a range of tasks, including writing thank-you notes, getting back to the pre-baby weight, ordering diapers and other necessities, and calming the little one.

items.title: Energy Secretary Is Resigning After 4 Years Focused on Clean Technologies
items.author: By Matthew L. Wald
items.abstract: Energy Secretary Steven Chu, a winner of the Nobel Prize, will leave office soon, possibly by the end of this month.

items.title: Peter Som’s Digital Runway
items.author: By Erika Allen
items.abstract: The designer gave up his coveted spot at the tents for a digital presentation. The benefits, he believes, outweigh the sacrifices.

items.title: That Tesla Data: What It Says and What It Doesn’t
items.author: By John M. Broder
items.abstract: About three hours into the trip, the reporter placed the first of about a dozen calls to Tesla personnel expressing concern about the car’s declining range.

items.title: A Digital Shift on Health Data Swells Profits in an Industry
items.author: By Julie Creswell
items.abstract: As doctors and hospitals struggle to make new records systems work, the winners are big companies that lobbied for the legislation that allowed their sales to soar.

items.title: The Promise and Peril of the ‘Data-Driven Society’
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: The prospect of a “data-driven society” was the subject of a gathering last Thursday at the M.I.T. Media Lab — the implications, the concerns and the unknowns. For example, the most important data that is becoming available on a vast new scale is information about people’s behavior: the social and economic connections among individuals.

items.title: U.A.E. Makes Huge Investment in Education and Technology
items.author: By Sara Hamdan
items.abstract: Sheik Nahayan bin Mubarak al-Nahayan, the minister of higher education, speaks about the U.A.E.'s enormous allocation for education, which totals more than one-fifth of the national budget.

items.title: Big Data Is Opening Doors, but Maybe Too Many
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: The dawn of mainframe computers offered huge technological benefits, but also challenged notions of privacy. Now Big Data is bringing similar expectations and concerns.

items.title: From Street Smart to Safari Savvy
items.author: By Suzy Menkes
items.abstract: Alexander Wang and Olivier Rousteing, for Balmain, offered collections that were very different but had the same spirit of sport.

items.title: Iran Agrees to Provide Data on Its Detonators
items.author: By Thomas Erdbrink
items.abstract: A deal reached with the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog called for additional inspections of known nuclear sites and more information about uranium mines and other facilities.

items.title: Technology Gives Ski Jumping Hills a Boost
items.author: By Ken Belson
items.abstract: The ski jumping hills at the Sochi Games are of a newer variety, with flatter, smoother curves on the inrun, and the facility has little snow around it.

items.title: Is the Universe a Simulation?
items.author: By Edward Frenkel
items.abstract: If so, that would help explain some mysterious things about math.

items.title: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
items.author: By Todd Woody
items.abstract: A project developed by WaterFX, a start-up in drought-stricken California, exploits two things the Central Valley possesses in abundance — fallow land and sunshine — to cut desalinization costs.

items.title: Wind Industry’s New Technologies Are Helping It Compete on Price
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.

items.title: Technology That Transforms Life (and Mutual Funds’ Returns)
items.author: By Tim Gray
items.abstract: Cloud computing, personalized medicine, robotics and other tech innovations brought big returns for some mutual funds in the first quarter.

items.title: More Deportations Follow Minor Crimes, Records Show
items.author: By Ginger Thompson and Sarah Cohen
items.abstract: Two-thirds of the nearly two million people deported since President Obama took office had committed only minor infractions or had no criminal record, a New York Times analysis has found.

items.title: Trying to Dam a Digital Sea
items.author: By Bina Shah
items.abstract: Pakistan’s ban on YouTube has exposed a struggle over freedom of expression.

items.title: At the International CES, the Internet of Things Hits Home
items.author: By Molly Wood
items.abstract: Household devices that link together through the Internet are likely to energize this year’s International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

items.title: Obama to Call for Laws Covering Data Hacking and Student Privacy
items.author: By Michael D. Shear and Natasha Singer
items.abstract: The announcement is part of a weeklong focus on privacy and cybersecurity by President Obama ahead of his State of the Union address on Jan. 20.

items.title: Economic Data From China, and Stimulus From the E.C.B.
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: China will release its fourth-quarter growth on Monday night, and on Thursday the European Central Bank is expected to start its bond-buying program; IBM and General Electric will report results.

items.title: ‘Black Mirror’ and the Horrors and Delights of Technology
items.author: By Jenna Wortham
items.abstract: A brilliant British TV show reflects a modern-day dystopia, made in America.

items.title: Apple to Open Giant Data Center in Arizona
items.author: By Brian X. Chen
items.abstract: The company plans to invest $2 billion in creating a data center in Mesa, Ariz., after it dropped plans to produce sapphire, a hardened and light material, at the facility.

items.title: Grid Sensors Could Ease Disruptions of Power
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: Utilities are experimenting with new systems that can monitor the flow of electricity and pinpoint failures more quickly, perhaps even avoiding them.

items.title: Mutual Suspicion Mars Tech Trade With China
items.author: By Jane Perlez and Paul Mozur
items.abstract: With China and the United States wary of the other’s digital espionage, American tech companies are caught in the middle.

items.title: Jobs Data in Europe and U.S., and Car Sales
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Employment figures will come on Monday for the eurozone, and on Friday for the United States; automakers will report their February sales.

items.title: U.S. Growth and Employment Data Tell Different Stories
items.author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
items.abstract: A divergence in the figures on hiring and output might be explained in part by the changing nature of the American economy.

items.title: Inquiry in China Adds to Doubt Over Reliability of Its Economic Data
items.author: By Keith Bradsher
items.abstract: As the country’s stock markets fall, an investigation into the head of the statistics agency could cloud efforts to gauge the weakening growth.

items.title: U.S. Economy Barely Grew Last Quarter, Stoking Concerns About Momentum in 2016
items.author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
items.abstract: The economy is facing headwinds like turmoil in global markets, but the job and housing markets remain strong.

items.title: Microsoft Plumbs Ocean’s Depths to Test Underwater Data Center
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: Microsoft sank a data center on the ocean floor, where the sea water acts as a coolant, and plans to use the waves to power it. The results were encouraging enough to try a bigger version.

items.title: Morning Agenda: Honeywell and United Technologies Disagree on Merits of Merger
items.author: By Amie Tsang
items.abstract: China Feels the Chill | New Energy Investment Vehicle Raises $450 Million | JPMorgan Tries to Calm Investors

items.title: Honeywell Persists in Pursuit of United Technologies
items.author: By Leslie Picker and Michael J. de la Merced
items.abstract: United Technologies responded to Honeywell’s latest bid with a presentation outlining its concerns about antitrust problems.

items.title: VW Whistle-Blower’s Suit Accuses Carmaker of Deleting Data
items.author: By Jack Ewing
items.abstract: A fired Volkswagen employee in Michigan contends that employees erased electronic files as U.S. officials were investigating its emissions cheating.

items.title: Water Is Broken. Data Can Fix It.
items.author: By Charles Fishman
items.abstract: Measuring something once every five years doesn’t give us the information we need.

items.title: IHS and Markit, Providers of Data and Analytics, Agree to Merge
items.author: By Leslie Picker
items.abstract: The combined company, IHS Markit, will provide services to more than 50,000 customers and will have about $3.3 billion in annual revenue.

items.title: S.E.C. Orders Exxon Mobil Shareholder Vote on Climate Data
items.author: By Liam Stack
items.abstract: A resolution, if approved, would force the energy giant to outline for investors how its profitability may be affected by climate change.

items.title: Can Carbon Capture Technology Prosper Under Trump?
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: Progress has come in fits and starts, but supporters believe a new plant in Texas may provide a clear economic argument for fighting global warming.

items.title: A Holistic Facialist’s Guide to Total Wellness
items.author: By Alainna Lexie Beddie
items.abstract: If Tess Adams of Take Care spa can’t fix what ails you with facials or massage or microcurrent technology, she knows just where in New York to send you.

items.title: Falcons, Drones, Data: A Winery Battles Climate Change
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Jackson Family Wines is among California winemakers employing both high-tech and old-school techniques to adapt to hotter, drier conditions.

items.title: Intercepted Russian Communications Part of Inquiry Into Trump Associates
items.author: By Michael S. Schmidt, Matthew Rosenberg, Adam Goldman and Matt Apuzzo
items.abstract: It is not clear whether the communications had anything to do with Donald J. Trump or his campaign.
keywords: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

items.title: Smart Approaches, Not Strong-Arm Tactics, to Jobs
items.author: By Thomas L. Friedman
items.abstract: Democrats need to take the long view.

items.title: Ford to Invest $1 Billion in Artificial Intelligence Start-Up
items.author: By Mike Isaac and Neal E. Boudette
items.abstract: The automaker will be the majority shareholder Argo AI, which will focus on developing self-driving vehicle technology.

items.title: Activists Rush to Save Government Science Data — If They Can Find It
items.author: By Amy Harmon
items.abstract: The Trump administration has begun changing some government websites. A group of concerned citizens has been working to preserve data it sees as politically vulnerable.

items.title: Trump Leaves Science Jobs Vacant, Troubling Critics
items.author: By Cecilia Kang and Michael D. Shear
items.abstract: Scores of scientists and technology experts have left the White House, and conservatives — and the president — have questioned whether they need to be replaced.

items.title: To Curb Global Warming, Science Fiction May Become Fact
items.author: By Eduardo Porter
items.abstract: Geoengineering, providing methods to offset climate change by applying scientific fixes rather than changing old habits, may have found its moment.
keywords: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

items.title: On the Whole30 Diet, Vowing to Eat ‘Smarter’ Carbs for More Than 30 Days
items.author: By Larissa Zimberoff
items.abstract: I have Type 1 diabetes. The Whole30 diet, with no wheat, dairy or sugar, made my blood sugar levels perfect.

items.title: Data on Europe’s Economy, Job Numbers and Janet Yellen’s Goodbye
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: The Fed meeting this week, Janet Yellen’s last as chairwoman will probably pass quietly, while earnings season for tech companies begins with a bang.

items.title: This Valentine’s Day, Considering Tech That Keeps Couples Together
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Technology has invaded modern relationships. Our Modern Love editor, Daniel Jones, says the most important tech for couples may be the shower.

items.title: Data Firm Tied to Trump Campaign Talked Business With Russians
items.author: By Danny Hakim and Matthew Rosenberg
items.abstract: Cambridge Analytica, a company that developed technology to target voters, has denied having connections to Russia. But evidence suggests otherwise.
keywords: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

items.title: Driverless Car Technology
items.abstract: A reader writes that while engineers work out gaping holes in the technology, we should turn our attention to fixing mass transit.

items.title: U.S. Charges 9 Iranians in Huge Theft of Intellectual Property
items.author: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: The suspects worked at the Mabna Institute, a contractor for the Iranian government, which benefited from the sensitive information obtained in the hacks, officials said.

items.title: For the U.S. and China, a Technology Cold War That’s Freezing Over
items.author: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur
items.abstract: In advanced industries like chip development, the rivals are vying for dominance in a fight that is as much about national security as economic might.

items.title: Facebook’s Zuckerberg Said to Agree to Testify Before Congress Over Data Privacy
items.author: By Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel
items.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has agreed to testify in Washington over how his social network handled people’s data, according to people familiar with the decision.
keywords: House Committee on Energy and Commerce

items.title: 2019 Was a Record Year for Ocean Temperatures, Data Show
items.author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
items.abstract: A new analysis found 2019 was the hottest for the world’s oceans. The five hottest years have also been in the past five years.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations
items.author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Also this week, African climate activists and a popular Berkeley class

items.title: Faulty Iowa App Was Part of Push to Restore Democrats’ Digital Edge
items.author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Nick Corasaniti, Sheera Frenkel and Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: The app that sowed chaos at the caucuses was the work of Shadow Inc., a group founded by veterans of the Clinton campaign.

items.title: Tesla Faces a New S.E.C. Investigation
items.author: By Niraj Chokshi
items.abstract: The electric-car maker said the agency was also looking into contracts and “regular financing arrangements.”

items.title: We May Be Living in a Simulation, but the Truth Still Matters
items.author: By Kara Swisher
items.abstract: Even if life is just a high-tech game, I’m comforted by our scientific superheroes.

items.title: The U.S. Sought Passenger Data, but Airlines Said No
items.abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

items.title: 5 Movies to Watch if You Have Trouble With Technology
items.author: By Mekado Murphy
items.abstract: These films creatively show the good and the not-so-good of the relationship between smart machines and humans.

items.title: ‘We Can Do Better’: One Plan to Erase America’s Digital Divide
items.author: By Shira Ovide
items.abstract: Never has the necessity of the internet been so clear, nor has the cost to those who go without.

items.title: Look to Wisconsin for Lessons on a Digital Campaign During a Pandemic
items.author: By Nick Corasaniti
items.abstract: “Democrats were organizing with every tool that didn’t require crossing the six-foot social distancing barrier,” the chair of the state Democratic Party said.

items.title: Three New Books on the Predigital Technologies That Shaped Our World
items.author: By Michael Strevens
items.abstract: A history of early medicine, a medieval astronomer’s adventures and an exploration of wood’s importance in human history all look back to eras long before the internet.
keywords: The Invention of Medicine: From Homer to Hippocrates (Book)
The Light Ages: The Surprising Story of Medieval Science (Book)
The Age of Wood: Our Most Useful Material and the Construction of Civilization (Book)

items.title: Can Technology Help Us Eat Better?
items.author: By Anahad O'Connor
items.abstract: A new crop of digital health companies is using blood glucose monitors to transform the way we eat.

items.title: Arianna Rosenbluth Dies at 93; Pioneering Figure in Data Science
items.author: By Katie Hafner
items.abstract: Dr. Rosenbluth, who received her physics Ph.D. at 21, helped create an algorithm that has become a foundation of understanding huge quantities of data. She died of complications of the coronavirus.

items.title: The Coming Technology Boom
items.author: By David Brooks
items.abstract: Politics is grim but science is working.

items.title: Review: Beware the Text, and Other Tales From ‘Smithtown’
items.author: By Jesse Green
items.abstract: Four not-very-believable characters in a chain of monologues are rescued by a cast of exceptionally believable actors.

items.title: Balancing Privacy With Data Sharing for the Public Good
items.author: By David Deming
items.abstract: Socially valuable data can be combined with standards that safeguard individual privacy, an economist says.
keywords: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

items.title: A Digital Festival, in the Spirit of Bertolt Brecht
items.author: By A.J. Goldmann
items.abstract: The directors of the Brecht Festival Augsburg have curated an online-only event that runs the gamut from experimental films to poetry slams and puppetry.

items.title: How Not to Get Fooled by the New Inflation Numbers
items.author: By Neil Irwin
items.abstract: Today’s data reflects backward-looking information, which is not necessarily a sign of what’s ahead.

items.title: In Coinbase’s Rise, a Reminder: Cryptocurrencies Use Lots of Energy
items.author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
items.abstract: The company’s stock market arrival establishes Bitcoin and other digital currencies in the traditional financial landscape. It also elevates a technology with astonishing environmental costs.

items.title: How a Multimedia Whiz Seized Digital Theater’s Big Moment
items.author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
items.abstract: The projection designer Jared Mezzocchi has become a go-to guy for ambitious virtual productions. Next up: Starring in his own haunted house play.

items.title: Why Do They Swim-Bike-Run So Fast? Data.
items.author: By Adam Skolnick
items.abstract: The most advanced science in the triathlon world can be found in Norway, where athletes embrace the data found in heat sensors, oxygen measuring masks and their feces.

items.title: I Ditched My Smart Watch, and I Don’t Regret It
items.author: By Lindsay Crouse
items.abstract: I didn’t know how my workout had gone, or how I’d slept last night, until I opened the app.

items.title: The Week in Business: A Step Toward Data Privacy
items.author: By Sarah Kessler
items.abstract: Americans kept shopping last month. China’s sunny version of the Olympics. And the potential impact on energy markets of a  Ukraine invasion.

items.title: Soccer’s Fastest-Growing Market Is the One for Ideas
items.author: By Rory Smith
items.abstract: Wealthy teams accustomed to pursuing players are simultaneously competing for the signatures of a new era’s most sought-after talents: data analysts.

items.title: Should Tech Stay or Go in Russia?
items.author: By Shira Ovide
items.abstract: Tech companies seem eager to support Ukraine, but how best to do that isn’t as clear.

items.title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
items.author: By Ana Swanson
items.abstract: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Volunteer Hackers Converge on Ukraine Conflict With No One in Charge
items.author: By Kate Conger and Adam Satariano
items.abstract: The hackers have claimed a number of disruptions over the past week, blurring the lines between amateurs and groups linked to governments.

items.title: A Paranoid Person’s Guide to Preparing for Digital Danger
items.author: By Ron Lieber
items.abstract: Russia’s attack may have you wondering what will happen if the conflict spills into cyberthreats beyond Ukraine’s borders. Here’s what you can do to ease your mind.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: U.S. Courts India as Technology Partner to Counter China
items.author: By Ana Swanson
items.abstract: American and Indian officials are working toward new partnerships in defense technology, advanced telecom and semiconductors.

items.title: Beyond Silicon Valley, Spending on Technology Is Resilient
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: Despite an uncertain outlook, corporations plan to continue investing in their digital projects — a source of stability for the economy.

items.title: Ford Will Build a U.S. Battery Factory With Technology From China
items.author: By Neal E. Boudette and Keith Bradsher
items.abstract: Ford’s $3.5 billion plant in Michigan will draw on technology from CATL, a Chinese company that is the world’s No. 1 maker of electric-car batteries.

items.title: Hackers Breach U.S. Marshals System With Sensitive Personal Data
items.author: By Glenn Thrush and Chris Cameron
items.abstract: The compromised computer system includes information on both investigative targets and agency employees.

items.title: New Data Links Pandemic’s Origins to Raccoon Dogs at Wuhan Market
items.author: By Benjamin Mueller
items.abstract: Genetic samples from the market were recently uploaded to an international database and then removed after scientists asked China about them.

items.title: Justice Dept. Investigating TikTok’s Owner Over Possible Spying on Journalists
items.author: By Glenn Thrush and Sapna Maheshwari
items.abstract: The inquiry appears to be tied to an admission by the app’s owner, ByteDance, that employees had inappropriately obtained Americans’ data. The company said it had fired the workers involved.
keywords: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

items.title: W.H.O. Accuses China of Hiding Data That May Link Covid’s Origins to Animals
items.author: By Benjamin Mueller
items.abstract: Genetic research from China suggests to some experts that the coronavirus may have sprung from a seafood market in Wuhan. Now the data are missing from a scientific database.
